column4: lol did a convert on my windows drive to make it FAT32...now it reads as only 24gb :|

just curios, I currently have linux on a 10gb partition of 120gb harddrive.. I'm going to get a new 200gb harddrive next weekend and I want to know ..will it be easier to convert the entire existing drive to linux (delete windows partitions and resize linux) or can I just dump linux onto the new drive?
nooooooooo I've just gotten everything configured right..excepting tv-out :\
hah 32 :)

well if you rephrased that as what would you advise I would suggest that you partition the disk a bit more into / /swap /usr /home /var /randomnames and then install hoary/warty/ and now for the real fun mount the *other* [old]  partition and copy the user data into the /home directory but not the config files and enjoy it
and taking into consideration your 'nooooooo' I would say you have the old configs and the new configs and you can manage that I imagine :)
i should be fine :) ... i can always come running and crying to this channel
there is a school of thought that blocking icmp is just evil /me points at a $companies firewall
i can enable it ..but for what?
also if configured properly it should not be an issue
it is used to keep various parts of the internet unbroken :)
your simple statement about your father was 19230769 times wrong
if everything here was documented, I would stop having the semblence of knowledge
now you know yourself that is not true :)
stop hurting my head..it's coming up to 5.30 am
ahh vic - I have only been in nsw and fnq
well I started off in cairns and went north
well I am a paddy
and I was drinking a lot of water, one (1.5l) bottle for the top of my head and the other one for inside me

there are exactly several methods more than you need, you are free to choose one that is there or create a new way :)

and broken software :) .. see the redmond sample for concepts of what might happen
a multi-billion dollar international company?
ahh yeah but, the internet is broken and it is all your fault
some programs where you get high volume output and you want to capture it at the same time can be run as follows: sudo tcpdump -l | tee > some logfile
meant to say run and see output at the same time
I tried doing a > to a file name and it gave me a 0 byte file :|
programname options | tee foolog   <<< that works sorry I think I left my brain in bed
what program are you using?
wget
what is the command you are issuing?
wget :P
wget https://www.anz.com/wholesale/bankmain.asp?AFFID=01025 -d | tee test
okay I have to eat - breakfast is served I will look at it when I get back
run this >> more bankmain.asp\?AFFID\=01025
im tired, gimme the exact syntax
I ran what you showed me last - the wget command line with url and tee and I then typed that more command
your command line is foobarred :)

I suggest you look at this >  wget -o log https://www.anz.com/wholesale/bankmain.asp?AFFID=01025 < this outputs a file (a) log and a file which is the last part of the url in this case (b) bankmain.asp?AFFID=01025 you can use the command less bankmain.asp?AFFID=01025 or more bankmain.asp?AFFID=01025  cat bankmain.asp?AFFID=01025 | more {or less} :) and see in case (a) what happened (b) what data you actually sucked
break it up it is lots of little things
it is not hard it just looks it
... I understand it ..thankyou :)
grand, and a happy paddy's day whats left of it
no

there is no output, so I would be inclined to look at top /ps to see if the program kicked off - I would also be looking at cpdump to see what was coming back across the wire when you made the request
that is tcpdump -lvv but you know that :)

so you need to fix your repositries

ehh ignore that
ReiserFS: $disk: warning: watch me loose your data faster then you can put it on the disk (okay thats not fair but it ate months of stuff on me a couple of years ago)
should I try reiserfsck to rebuild the superblock?
ya
ya should do that
now I'm getting Bad root block 0 :|
ooch
gime a min with a book or two and lets see if I have anything that might be useful for that
if you offer the following to the command line what do you get back? fsck -y /dev/sda1 ?
the fsck command should have some brains to figure out what it is looking at
#flood
should I boot to liveCD and do a fsck on the whole drive? my rootFS is reiserFS as well and no problems
that is a good idea - have you got a spare disk like sdb hanging around?
only a network drive..most of my data, including my backup, was on my 90gb partition
arrrrrr
it's no biggy..most of the partition was music vids (43gb)
well it looks like the safest thing to do is to boot from that livecd
well I would try the live cd
and then move data around until you can kill the partition and start again

at least once every development cycle
